channel.title: National Geographic News
channel.description: Reporting our world daily: original nature and science news from National Geographic.

item.title: How to see the Lyrid meteor shower
item.description: One of the oldest annual showers on record, the Lyrids put on a show each spring.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Fazekas

item.title: 49 environmental victories since the first Earth Day
item.description: As Earth Day turns 49, we take a look back at the biggest milestones in environmental protection.
item.dc:creator: Brian Clark Howard

item.title: How the world celebrates Easter in 18 spectacular photos
item.description: From eggs to bunnies, there are almost as many ways to observe Easter as there are countries.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: Historian uses lasers to unlock mysteries of Gothic cathedrals
item.description: A tech-savvy art historian uses lasers to understand how medieval builders constructed their architectural masterpieces.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Hartigan Shea

item.title: A running list of how President Trump is changing environmental policy
item.description: The Trump administration has promised vast changes to U.S. science and environmental policy—and we’re tracking them here as they happen.
item.dc:creator: Michael Greshko

item.title: These pictures made photographic history
item.description: From a close-up of a spider to the first underwater color photos, these pioneering pictures capture the spirit of exploration.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: Gotcha! History's Most Outrageous April Fools' Jokes
item.description: Learn about these clever April Fools' Day hoaxes and pranks, including the famous Swiss spaghetti harvest.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: Bomb cyclones and polar vortexes—winter's scary weather explained
item.description: What creates these dramatic-sounding weather conditions?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gibbens

item.title: Specific Stonehenge quarries identified by new research
item.description: Two ancient quarries some 180 miles from the famed prehistoric monument have been identified as the source for stones in the monument’s inner circle.
item.dc:creator: Nick Romeo

item.title: First mammal species recognized as extinct due to climate change
item.description: The humble Bramble Cay melomys has disappeared from its island in the Great Barrier Reef.
item.dc:creator: Brian Clark Howard

item.title: From St. Nicholas to Santa Claus: the surprising origins of Kris Kringle
item.description: Santa Claus, Father Christmas, St. Nick—no matter the name, everyone knows the story of this plump, jolly, bringer of gifts. Or do they?
item.dc:creator: Brian Handwerk

item.title: Where's Santa buried? Resting places of the real St. Nick
item.description: The mortal remains of the 4th-century Greek bishop are likely scattered around the world as holy relics.
item.dc:creator: Brian Handwerk

item.title: When is the first day of winter? December solstice 2018 explained.
item.description: Find out how astronomy and meteorology differ on the definition, why solstices happen, and how the day is marked around the world.
item.dc:creator: Brian Handwerk

item.title: A whopping 91% of plastic isn't recycled
item.description: Billions of tons of plastic have been made over the past decades, and much of it is becoming trash and litter, finds the first analysis of the issue.
item.dc:creator: Laura Parker

item.title: Fast facts about plastic pollution
item.description: Versatile, pliable, durable, cheap to produce—and ubiquitous. Plastic is all of that. It is also both a life-saving miracle product and the scourge of the Earth. Here are eight essential facts to keep in mind.
item.dc:creator: Laura Parker

item.title: We visited the border wall. Here's what it looks like.
item.description: In 2016, our photographer visited the heavily guarded—and completely empty—parts of the 2,000-mile-long U.S.-Mexico border.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Stone

item.title: Both of NASA's Voyager spacecraft are now interstellar. Where to next?
item.description: Launched in 1977, the twin probes will likely outlive the sun. Find out what star systems they’ll meet as they head deeper into the galaxy.
item.dc:creator: Nadia Drake

item.title: This notorious Christmas character is dividing a country
item.description: Neo-Nazis in the Netherlands have responded violently to calls to get rid of Santa's blackface holiday assistant.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: Who is Krampus? Explaining the horrific Christmas beast
item.description: Santa's got some competition: a terrifying Christmas devil named Krampus, which is catching on in pop culture worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Basu

item.title: Turkeys can swim—and other fun facts for Thanksgiving table talk
item.description: There's much more to America's holiday bird than white and dark meat.
item.dc:creator: Mark Strauss

item.title: Are marsquakes anything like earthquakes? NASA is about to find out.
item.description: A new spacecraft that's due to land soon on Mars will investigate why and how much the red planet rumbles.
item.dc:creator: Nadia Drake

item.title: A few things you (probably) don’t know about Thanksgiving
item.description: The pilgrims stole from graves, the Wampanoag were devastated by disease, and the peace between them was political.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: How World War I launched mapmaking at National Geographic
item.description: This Veterans Day marks the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I. It was during the war that National Geographic Society began producing original maps.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: 'Biggest case on the planet' pits kids vs. climate change
item.description: A pioneering lawsuit against the U.S. government has won the right to a trial, overcoming the Trump administration's efforts to cancel it in court.
item.dc:creator: Laura Parker

item.title: The map that popularized the word ‘gerrymander’
item.description: The practice wasn’t new in 1812. But a map in a newspaper gave it a name that stuck.
item.dc:creator: Greg Miller

item.title: Why do we have daylight saving time? 100 years of history
item.description: Get the facts about springing forward and falling back, a tradition that was established in the U.S. in 1918.
item.dc:creator: Erin Blakemore

item.title: Everything you need to know about Halloween 2018
item.description: From the holiday’s Celtic history to this year’s top costumes, here’s what to know to have a smart and scary holiday.
item.dc:creator: Brian Handwerk

item.title: Five of Museum of the Bible's Dead Sea Scrolls are forgeries
item.description: With the museum’s support, scholars are racing to understand the disputed Biblical texts.
item.dc:creator: Michael Greshko

item.title: 12 extraordinary pictures show animals headed for extinction
item.description: There are thousands of species that may not be around for long.
item.dc:creator: Anna Lukacs

item.title: 15 spooky houses for Halloween
item.description: We're definitely creeped out by this photo gallery.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: What’s really in Antarctica’s mysterious blood falls
item.description: The eerily gory waterfall is not in fact made of blood, and a new study shows just what gives it its unique color.
item.dc:creator: Delaney Ross

item.title: Meet 5 "zombie" parasites that mind-control their hosts
item.description: It's no Halloween movie—some parasites hijack their hosts' brains to make them act in horrific ways.
item.dc:creator: Mary Bates

item.title: 6 ghostly animals just in time for Halloween
item.description: From a deep-sea shark to a dancing moth, some wild animals have earned a spooky reputation.
item.dc:creator: Liz Langley

item.title: Take me out to the ball game: 15 unique baseball photos
item.description: From a bat factory to Amish Country to the World Series, see our favorite baseball photos from the National Geographic archives.
item.dc:creator: Melody Rowell

item.title: These animals’ screams will chill your blood
item.description: The spookiest sounds on Halloween are made by creatures of the night.
item.dc:creator: James Owen

item.title: Halloween: costumes, history, myths, and more
item.description: Get the facts on Halloween's history and why we love it so much today.
item.dc:creator: Brian Handwerk

item.title: Wreckage of WWII-era warship U.S.S. Indianapolis found after 72 years
item.description: A search led by billionaire Paul Allen locates the cruiser at the bottom of the Philippine Sea.
item.dc:creator: Christina Nunez

item.title: Sunken World War II aircraft carrier found by deep-sea expedition
item.description: Known for deep-sea exploration efforts uncovering military ships in the past, Paul Allen's personal search team has helped to discover a lost aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: How Microsoft billionaire found largest sunken battleship
item.description: High-tech tools, including an undersea "mountain goat," and years of research led to the discovery of the WWII-era Musashi in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Romey

item.title: Cecil the Lion Died Amid Controversy—Here's What's Happened Since
item.description: Cecil’s killing sparked what’s been called the biggest global response to a wildlife story ever.
item.dc:creator: Jani Actman

item.title: 9 countries and the EU protected the Arctic Ocean before the ice melts
item.description: Climate change is so quickly melting the far north that key nations just agreed to prohibit commercial fishing in the high seas of the Arctic for at least 16 years.
item.dc:creator: Craig Welch

item.title: Who Are the Nobel Prize Winners? We've Crunched the Numbers.
item.description: We dove into 115 years’ worth of past laureates, and the data revealed some striking trends.
item.dc:creator: Michael Greshko

item.title: These countries changed their names. Here's how it worked out.
item.description: Macedonia's movement to rename itself is the latest in a series of shifts in country names around the world. Here's a look back at some of the most famous.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Leahy

item.title: Halloween Costume Pictures: Spooky Styles a Century Ago
item.description: From roller skates to swastikas, see how people in the early 1900s celebrated what one expert calls the United States' "rogue holiday."

item.title: Will Indonesia Be Ready for the Next Tsunami?
item.description: After a 2004 catastrophic tsunami killed nearly 170,000 people in Indonesia, is the country ready for the next one?
item.dc:creator: Tim Folger

item.title: The Fall Equinox Is Here! Wait, What's the Fall Equinox?
item.description: It comes twice a year and marks the first day of fall, but a lot of people don't understand this celestial alignment.
item.dc:creator: Rachel A. Becker

item.title: No, Captain Cook's Ship Hasn't Been Found Yet
item.description: What we know and don't know about the wreck of the H.M.B. Endeavour.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Romey

item.title: Remembering 9/11 in Pictures
item.description: Indelible photos mark one of America's darkest days.
item.dc:creator: Becky Little

item.title: Snakeless in Ireland: Blame Ice Age, Not St. Patrick
item.description: One man is credited with taking all snakes out of Ireland, but science tells a different story.

item.title: Would a U.S. Space Force Be Legal? Get the Facts.
item.description: As the Trump Administration calls for a new military branch, get the plan's pros and cons and learn the rules governing off-world soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Greshko

item.title: What Do Wild Animals Do in Wildfires?
item.description: Big wildfires, like those tearing through Northern California, can hurt some animals—while others escape, and some species even thrive.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Zielinski

item.title: 5 Reasons to Like the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
item.description: It keeps a lot of dangerous stuff from being dumped in our air, water, and land.
item.dc:creator: Brian Clark Howard

item.title: Living Fireworks, These Animals Produce Light Shows with Their Bodies
item.description: A variety of animals produce bioluminescent light, creating signals that can be used for mating and communication.
item.dc:creator: Liz Langley

item.title: Rule to Allow Hunting Could Doom Rare Red Wolves
item.description: Wildlife experts aren’t keen on a plan by the government to allow private landowners to shoot wolves living on their land.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: Learning to Love Dogs in Kigali
item.description: Rwandans are embracing dogs as pets in spite of the country’s dark canine history.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

item.title: The Last Cowboys: A Cattle-Ranching Family Fights to Survive
item.description: Bucking broncs, drought, and tourism are just a few challenges for the Wright family’s 150-year-old way of life.
item.dc:creator: Simon Worrall

item.title: Headless Pompeii Victim Wasn't Crushed to Death, After All
item.description: A surprising new discovery reveals the truth about what really happened to an unfortunate man in 79 A.D.
item.dc:creator: Erin Blakemore

item.title: Why This Zoo Lion Killed a Lost Water Bird
item.description: When a heron inexplicably ended up in the lion enclosure, the big cat’s instincts sprung into action.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: What's Giving Some Beachgoers Rashes? Get the Facts.
item.description: Lifeguards reported this year’s first cases of sea lice, which aren’t lice at all.
item.dc:creator: Theresa Machemer

item.title: Humans Gave Leprosy to Armadillos. Now, They’re Giving It Back
item.description: Wild armadillo meat is popular in Brazil, but a new study shows those who eat it put themselves at risk of contracting leprosy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bittel

item.title: Meet the 'Kickboxing Grannies' of Kenya's Most Dangerous Slum
item.description: A group of grandmothers hailing from Korogocho have come together to protect and empower themselves and their community.
item.dc:creator: Lauren O'Brien

item.title: Gorgeous Panoramic Paintings of National Parks Now Online
item.description: The iconic illustrations by Austrian artist Heinrich Berann have been digitized in high resolution for the first time, three decades after they were created.
item.dc:creator: Betsy Mason

item.title: Right Stuff for Life Found on Small Saturn Moon
item.description: Data from a dead spacecraft suggest that this world may be the best place besides Earth for life as we know it.
item.dc:creator: Nadia Drake

item.title: Coldest Place on Earth Found—Here's How
item.description: "It's a place where Earth is so close to its limit, it's almost like another planet."
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda

item.title: Why These Leopard Sisters Are Mating With the Same Male
item.description: This unusual arrangement was likely the result of the two females coincidentally going into heat at the same time.

item.title: 19 Eel Smugglers Sentenced, But Lucrative Trade Persists
item.description: With prices for baby eels soaring to a high of nearly $3,000 a pound, illegal traders continue to chance their luck with the police.
item.dc:creator: Rene Ebersole

item.title: Tropical Forest Loss Slowed in 2017—To the Second Worst Total Ever
item.description: Brazil and the Democratic Republic of the Congo lost the most; things improved in Indonesia. Here are five takeaways from a new report.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Leahy

item.title: Amid a Civil War, These Syrians Keep Dancing
item.description: The group calling themselves 'Dare' says they are using dance as an agent of change in a nation beset by conflict.
item.dc:creator: Heather Brady

item.title: How Ancient Mummies Helped This Soccer Player Get to the World Cup
item.description: After Paolo Guerrero tested positive for cocaine, scientists used Inca mummies to argue that the result may have been influenced by something else.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gibbens

item.title: National Geographic Explorer and Space Architect Dies at 53
item.description: A pioneer in her field, Constance Adams’ love of the solar system and Earth fueled her life’s work.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

item.title: What Does It Take to Raise a Flamingo?
item.description: A zoo celebrates as its flamingo flock gives birth to five new chicks—but the process is more difficult than it may seem.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth

item.title: Birds That Leave Nest Too Late Can Endanger Their Families
item.description: A baby bird’s ability to move and its chances of survival are closely tied, a new study finds.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: Could DNA Testing Reunite Immigrant Families? Get the Facts.
item.description: Genetic testing offers a potential solution to the crisis, but logistics and privacy concerns pose major challenges.
item.dc:creator: Maya Wei-Haas

item.title: Meet the Bug That Armors Itself With Shells
item.description: The caddisfly is one of many insects that get creative in shielding themselves from predators.
item.dc:creator: Liz Langley

item.title: Why the Short-Lived Pony Express Still Fascinates Us
item.description: The Pony Express operated for less than two years, but its legend—burnished by Buffalo Bill Cody—lives on.
item.dc:creator: Simon Worrall

item.title: Here’s What Makes a Dripping Faucet Go ‘Plink’
item.description: Annoyed by the persistent dripping of water in a bucket, one scientist set out to learn what creates the distinctive sound.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gibbens

item.title: Delusions of Infestation Aren't as Rare as You'd Think
item.description: More people are turning to entomologists to identify parasites they believe are crawling on their bodies, but which turn out not to be real.
item.dc:creator: Erika Engelhaupt

item.title: Could Humans and Dinosaurs Coexist? Here's the Science.
item.description: “The dinosaurs would be aliens in our world.”
item.dc:creator: John Pickrell

item.title: Why These Children Are Forced to Scale a 40-Foot Well
item.description: A short video shows young girls in India climbing into dangerous, deep wells to retrieve worm-infested water.
item.dc:creator: Heather Brady

item.title: World’s Biggest Pig Captured in Rare Video
item.description: The 600-pound giant forest hog is expert at avoiding people, who are increasingly hunting the animal in its African habitat.
item.dc:creator: Christine Dell'Amore

item.title: Smoking Ocean Vents Found in Surprisingly Shallow Water
item.description: Scientists have found new hydrothermal vents off the Azores, and they may harbor unique life.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Leahy

item.title: Orcas Slap, Kill, But Don't Eat Their Prey
item.description: It’s impossible to tell why the whales didn’t eat their prey, one expert says, but here are a few suggestions.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: Syphilis DNA Pulled From Colonial-Era Bones
item.description: The 350-year-old genes may help researchers settle the debate about where the disease originated.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gibbens

item.title: Ancient Royal Tomb Yields Strange New Ape Species
item.description: The toothy creature provides rare evidence of early human-caused extinctions.
item.dc:creator: Maya Wei-Haas

item.title: Den of Mountain Lion Kittens Found in Unlikely Place
item.description: National Park Service researchers discovered a litter of four cougar kittens near California’s Simi Hills, an area surrounded by highways.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth

item.title: Why Koko the Gorilla Mattered
item.description: Featured twice on the cover of National Geographic magazine, Koko led to major revelations about animal empathy and communication.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Main

item.title: UNESCO Biosphere Reserve Drops Monkey Circus
item.description: At Vietnam’s Can Gio reserve, monkeys performed tricks in subpar conditions. The circus has left—but the monkeys remain in possession of the corporation.
item.dc:creator: Rachael Bale

item.title: This Summer Solstice, Earth's Days Are Longer Than Ever
item.description: Earth hasn't always had a 24-hour day. Here's what that means for the June solstice.
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda

item.title: Why T. Rex Couldn't Waggle Its Tongue
item.description: Scientists were in for a surprise after peering inside the mouths of modern alligators and birds.
item.dc:creator: Theresa Machemer

item.title: Can Bees Help Save Elephants From Train Strikes?
item.description: In India, where elephants are hit by trains, people are trying innovative solutions.
item.dc:creator: Mary-Rose Abraham

item.title: This Bird Has Been Singing the Same Song for 1,000 Years
item.description: The American swamp sparrow’s amazing ability to pass down its song perfectly is an example of handing down a cultural tradition, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth

item.title: After Fleeing War, Refugee Children Face Lasting Psychological Trauma
item.description: In Lesbos, Greece, young refugees cope with a growing mental health crisis.
item.dc:creator: Nina Strochlic

item.title: Some Rivers Are So Drug-Polluted, Their Eels Get High on Cocaine
item.description: Illegal drug residues in the water could be affecting native fish.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rapp Learn

item.title: These Groundbreaking Photos Show Two Worlds in One
item.description: Photographer David Doubilet's "over-under" images present a view of the ocean most people will never get to experience.
item.dc:creator: Christina Nunez

item.title: Why This Rare Lobster Is Colored Like Blue Cotton Candy
item.description: The critter’s pastel rainbow hues may be the result of a genetic mutation or an unusual diet.
item.dc:creator: Maya Wei-Haas

item.title: Why Great White Sharks Hang Out in Warm Whirlpools
item.description: New research on famous white sharks Mary Lee and Lydia shows the giant fish spend a surprising amount of time in warm oceanic eddies.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Main

item.title: Leopard Plays With Prey’s Own Bones
item.description: Rare video shows big cat tearing open its warthog victim and perusing its innards with its jawbone.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: What Is Hogweed, the Invading Plant That Burns and Blinds?
item.description: The striking plant was brought to North America to decorate gardens and arboretums, but now officials are working to wipe it out.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gibbens

item.title: Nuns Resurrect Endangered Salamanders in First-of-its-Kind Conservation Effort
item.description: This may be the first time a religious group has been involved in amphibian breeding program, an expert says.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Zachos

item.title: These 38 Coral Reefs Are Thriving, Despite Threats
item.description: A new study found "oases" of resilient coral reefs around the world that are beating the odds against warming, pollution, and other impacts.
item.dc:creator: Theresa Machemer
